story.text: LONDON Jan 2 European shares hit their highest level in almost six years on Tuesday, after gains in Asia and helped by mining and telecoms stocks, but volumes were expected to be thin as U.S. markets were closed to mourn the death of former President Gerald Ford. At 0849 GMT the FTSEurofirst 300 .FTEU3 index of top European shares was up 0.9 points at 1,496.61 points in the first trading session of the new year, its highest since Feb. 2001, as stocks followed Asian shares higher. Among major national indexes, the UK's FTSE 100 was up 0.9 percent, Germany's DAX .GDAXI was up 1 percent, also at their highest since Feb. 2001, and France's CAC 40 gained 1.2 percent. The euro hit a record high against the yen, and gained against the dollar, buying $1.3278. The weak dollar lifted gold to its highest level in nearly a month, and oil prices stayed below $61 a barrel. "We remain positive for the year as a whole," said Deutsche Bank European strategist Bernd Meyer. "But macroeconomic uncertainties might result in a more bumpy ride in the next couple of weeks." Meyer said a lot depended on macroeconomic news such as interest rate decisions in the United States and the impact of the housing market, and fourth-quarter corporate results due later this month. "There were quite a lot of special factors that helped Q3 reporting. The fourth quarter could easily be less supportive of the market," he said. Among miners, BHP Billiton (BLT.L) was up 1.8 percent and Anglo American (AAL.L) rose 1.6 percent. Activity in Germany's manufacturing sector hit a six-month high in December, supported by accelerating growth in orders and output, a survey of purchasing managers released on Tuesday showed. But growth in French manufacturing slowed to its weakest in 10 months in December. Shares in French utility Suez LYOE.PA were up 1.8 percent after French billionaire Francois Pinault declined to rule out a possible bid for the company, adding to uncertainty around Suez's plan to merge with Gaz de France GAZ.PA. Shares in Veolia Environnement (VIE.PA), which had soared 9 percent on Friday, were the top losers in Europe. French press reports have said that Pinault will sell Suez's environmental business to Veolia. Shares in Anglo-Dutch steel group Corus CS.L were up 0.9 percent after Indian newspapers reported Tata Steel (TISC.BO) would raise its bid for the company.
story.title: european shares hit new highs , mining stocks help
